position.marginalia_text: Manlij Loci Communes; ad omnem Ciuilem discursum, pra[e]gnantissimus Commentarius, atq[ue] dulcissimus: Legenda Aurea Melancthonis; et Chytra[e]i Summa Angelica. Hic Dominicus; et ille Manlius, duo Spiritus Familiares Ang: Fu: Ad omnes Aulicos, et Pragmaticos Discursus, Facinora, et Arcana; nihil pra[e]gnantius, aut profundius, quàm Comitissa[e] Arcadia, et Apologia Herodoti; Rabela[e]sij Heroica, et Vnici Aretini Dialogi, et Comoedia[e]: cum Historijs Suetonij, et Taciti; stratagematis Gandini, et Polya[e]ni; arcanis Weccheri, et Cardani; Practicis Machiauelli, et Durandi. Nec unq[uam] absint duo Familiares Spiritus, Dominicus, et Manlius. Qui vbiq[ue] est, nusq[uam] est: Certis Ingenijs adha[e]rescendu[m].

marginalia.translation: Manlius' Common Places, the most pregnant and pleasing commentary for every civil discourse; Melancthon's Golden Legend; and Chytraeus' Angelic Summary. Here Domenichi and there Manlius, two spirits familiar to Angelus Furius. Discourses for all courtiers and pragmatic men, with deeds and secret matters. Nothing more pregnant and profound than the Countess of Pembroke's Arcadia and the Apology for Herodotus; the Heroic Tales of Rabelais; and the Dialogues and Comedis of Bernardo Accolti; with the Histories of Suetonius and Tacitus; the stratagems of Gandino and Polyaenus; the secret matters of Wecker and Cardano; the practical affairs of Machiavelli and Durand. But there will never be absent those two familiar spirits, Domenichi and Manlus. Whoever is everywhere is nowhere; you must stick to certain ingenius men.

position.marginalia_text: Zuingeri Theatrum, instar totius humanitatis: pra[e]sertim cum Ortelij theatro: et planeij Mappa vniuersali.

marginalia.translation: Zwinger's Theater, an example for all humanity, especially with Abraham Ortelius' theater, and with the universal map of the planets.

position.marginalia_text: Discursuum abunde est in vitali spiritu, animaliq[ue] phantasia. Vacat operibus ferè solis. Idiota est, cui non verò fluunt dicenda.

marginalia.translation: It abounds in the vital spirit and brute imagination of conversations. It is free from almost all works alone. An idiot is someone for whom things to be said do not truly flow.
